Problem:
Assume a linear system described by the Laplace equation \\(\Delta u = 0\\), where \\(u\\) is a complex function of a spatial variable. We investigate how the application of Fourier transformation, denoted by \\(\mathcal{F}\\), impacts the causal inference of effects in this system.

If the Fourier Transform \\(\mathcal{F}(u)\\) is applied to the function \\(u(x)\\) and it undergoes normal evolution under the Laplace equation, will the transformed state at spatial point and time \\(x, T\\) reflect only the properties of \\(\Delta u = 0\\) - without external influences?
Explanation: The Fourier Transform alters the domain from spatial to frequency, yet does not change the fundamental solutions of the Laplace equation since it is a linear operator. Hence, the evolution only reflects the inherent properties governed by \\(\Delta u = 0\\).
